physical_examinations.relevant_findings: Patient presented with lethargy, malaise, and a history of fever, arthralgia, and urticarial rash. Notable facial droop indicating possible facial hemiparesis.
physical_examinations.changes_over_time: The rash, fever, and facial droop resolved within a week, but the patient continued to experience somnolence and malaise.

physical_examinations.relevant_findings: Neurological evaluation indicated intermittent asymmetry with posterior right-hemisphere background slowing on EEG. MRI revealed scattered 1-2 mm punctate foci of signal abnormality in the subcortical white matter, predominantly in the frontal lobes.
physical_examinations.changes_over_time: Subsequent CT and EEG findings were reportedly normal, but the initial EEG showed abnormal activity.

physical_examinations.relevant_findings: Patient was noted to have markedly positive serum titers for Borrelia burgdorferi (Lyme disease). CSF was notable for normal protein and glucose content, with mild IgG reactivity.
physical_examinations.changes_over_time: After treatment with intravenous ceftriaxone, repeat Lyme serologies indicated higher than normal titers, and CSF revealed the presence of IgM antibodies consistent with acute Borrelia infection.
